snippet.textDisplay:
That decision was complete and utter bull💩!

The rule is: whether or not, the player in the offside position, has an effects on the play. (or interferes with play).

First point is: Does the player stop the keeper from saving the ball?
De Gea starts to dive to his right when the shot is taken. He his still moving right when the ball is deflected pass him. Why? Because he can not stop his bodies momentum and dive the other way in the time necessary to save that ball. (Regardless of whether he can see the ball or not).
So has the player stop the keeper from saving the ball? Answer: No

Second point is: does the player impede the keepers line of sight?
When the initial shot is taken he is not in the line of sight of the keeper. Once the defection has occurred the line of sight becomes irrelevant as it refers back to the first point, the goal keeper is in no position to save the ball even if he could see it.
So does the player impede the keepers line of sight? No

So you have a NO to both question that the referee must ask himself when ruling whether or not the player is interfering with play, therefore the goal should of stood.

Referees are not understanding and applying the rules as they are written. It is poor officiating. This is why the refereeing standards in the premier league has declined and will continue to decline as there is no accountability for poor decision making.
snippet.textOriginal:
That decision was complete and utter bull💩!

The rule is: whether or not, the player in the offside position, has an effects on the play. (or interferes with play). 

First point is: Does the player stop the keeper from saving the ball?
De Gea starts to dive to his right when the shot is taken. He his still moving right when the ball is deflected pass him. Why? Because he can not stop his bodies momentum and dive the other way in the time necessary to save that ball. (Regardless of whether he can see the ball or not). 
So has the player stop the keeper from saving the ball? Answer: No

Second point is: does the player impede the keepers line of sight?
When the initial shot is taken he is not in the line of sight of the keeper. Once the defection has occurred the line of sight becomes irrelevant as it refers back to the first point, the goal keeper is in no position to save the ball even if he could see it. 
So does the player impede the keepers line of sight? No 

So you have a NO to both question that the referee must ask himself when ruling whether or not the player is interfering with play, therefore the goal should of stood. 

Referees are not understanding and applying the rules as they are written. It is poor officiating. This is why the refereeing standards in the premier league has declined and will continue to decline as there is no accountability for poor decision making.

snippet.textDisplay: AFC Bournemouth fan here - so as you can imagine, I'm not too happy about VAR at the moment. But even taking that into account I think its fair to say that the VAR officials haven't shown the wisdom of Solomon with this one. Yes, the goal should be disallowed if there's an attacking player blocking the goalkeeper's line of sight, but here the attacker is SAT DOWN and the goalkeeper is STOOD UP. End of rant.
snippet.textOriginal: AFC Bournemouth fan here - so as you can imagine, I'm not too happy about VAR at the moment. But even taking that into account I think its fair to say that the VAR officials haven't shown the wisdom of Solomon with this one. Yes, the goal should be disallowed if there's an attacking player blocking the goalkeeper's line of sight, but here the attacker is SAT DOWN and the goalkeeper is STOOD UP. End of rant.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a Liverpool fan and this is a criminal decision by the referee.  I know why they gave the offside, because Sigurdsson was in an offside position and was deemed to be interfering with play from that position. But that doesn't mean they were right to give it. De Gea had no chance with that deflection regardless of Glyfi's position, and for me, De Gea could see the path of the ball over him. The rule was terribly applied here. Robbed.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a Liverpool fan and this is a criminal decision by the referee.  I know why they gave the offside, because Sigurdsson was in an offside position and was deemed to be interfering with play from that position. But that doesn't mean they were right to give it. De Gea had no chance with that deflection regardless of Glyfi's position, and for me, De Gea could see the path of the ball over him. The rule was terribly applied here. Robbed.

snippet.textDisplay: I can't see how pickford is at fault for the goal, how he had to redeem himself. You can see on the replay the shot was initially bottom corner then swerved inwards underneath him. It's a drilled shot just outside the box at the near post but pickford isn't a tall gk so he has to cover the outside a little more than other gks, I know from experience. Just because it went in from the near post underneath him shouldn't put him at fault. Sometimes shots like that are harder to save than shots into the corner completely due to how they go under your dive. You also have to consider the pace of the shot as replays are always slowed down massively. Then look at the defenders, why did no one look to box him out of the box when he was looking to shoot?
snippet.textOriginal: I can't see how pickford is at fault for the goal, how he had to redeem himself. snippet.textDisplay: What a shocking decision at the end, i think we need to start looking at changing decisions AFTER a game has finished if there's a mistake made. Too many of the big clubs getting favourable and unwarranted decisions based on their stature in my opinion... this result being one of those occasions. I feel for Everton and their fanbase as they got robbed of 2 points here.
snippet.textOriginal: What a shocking decision at the end, i think we need to start looking at changing decisions *AFTER* a game has finished if there's a mistake made. Too many of the big clubs getting favourable and unwarranted decisions based on their stature in my opinion... this result being one of those occasions. I feel for Everton and their fanbase as they got robbed of 2 points here.

snippet.textDisplay: Rules starting last year stating positioned players in front of the goalkeeper impacts the decision of the keeper so they made the new offside rule that even if a player does not touch the ball he can still be ruled offside for interfering with play he’s in goalkeeper view goalkeeper can’t see how far the ball is maybe it was going wide he couldn’t see so it infringed the play therefore no goal
snippet.textOriginal: Rules starting last year stating positioned players in front of the goalkeeper impacts the decision of the keeper so they made the new offside rule that even if a player does not touch the ball he can still be ruled offside for interfering with play he’s in goalkeeper view goalkeeper can’t see how far the ball is maybe it was going wide he couldn’t see so it infringed the play therefore no goal

snippet.textDisplay: Why do people think this goal shouldn’t have been disallowed? The ball would of hit the offside player if he didn’t move his legs and he did ergo effecting play. If he didn’t move and the ball went in the back of the net then it wouldn’t have been offside.
snippet.textOriginal: Why do people think this goal shouldn’t have been disallowed? The ball would of hit the offside player if he didn’t move his legs and he did ergo effecting play. If he didn’t move and the ball went in the back of the net then it wouldn’t have been offside.

I suppose next time he could stand up within 25 seconds from falling to the floor and everything will be fine. I just do not understand how it is even possible to conceive that a super paid pro in the last 2 min of a game stays on the floor and fixes his socks.
